questions.question: Which of the following fetal hormones does not play a role in fetal growth?
questions.explanation: Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, whereas insulin, glucocorticoids, and thyroxine all contribute to fetal development.

questions.question: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in 2-3 word sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
questions.explanation: The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences, which indicates the child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence, the child's weight should be 3 kgs x 4 = 12 Kgs. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd week.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
options.B: Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
options.C: A boy's height at 2 and a half years is half of his adult height
options.D: A girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.explanation: Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable. The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method. Head circumference increases by the following: 2 cm/month in the first 3 months, 1 cm/month in the next 3 months, and 0.5 cm/month in the next 6 months. Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth. At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference. At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference. After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference. Age - Head circumference: At birth - 33 to 35cm, 3 months - 40 cm, 6 months - 43 cm, 1 year - 46 cm, 2 years - 48 cm, 3 years - 49 cm, 4 years - 50 cm, 12 years - 52 cm (adult size).

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the eruption of teeth is false?
questions.explanation: Primary teeth in the upper jaw erupt earlier than their counterparts in the lower jaw, except for lower central incisors and second molars. No primary teeth until the age of 13 months is called delayed eruption. As seen in the image below, the first primary tooth to erupt is the lower (mandibular) central incisor, at 5-7 months. All primary teeth erupt by 1.5-2.5 years of age. The first secondary tooth to erupt is the first molar (maxillary or mandibular), at 6-7 years, followed by the lower central incisor. Causes of delayed eruption: • Idiopathic: Most common • Hypothyroidism, Hypoparathyroidism • Familial • Mechanical blockage of individual teeth

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.explanation: The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age, which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia the most likely among the given options. The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height. The U/L ratio is 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 years, 1 after 7 years, and 0.9 in adults. Pubic symphysis - upper segment, lower segment. High U/L ratio: Rickets, Achondroplasia, untreated congenital hypothyroidism. Low U/L ratio: Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia, vertebral anomalies. Arm span: the length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span. It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 years and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually <1 cm).

questions.question: A team participating in an Under-14 national athletics sports tournament suspects foul play by a rival team member. He claims to fit the criteria for the age requirements for the tournament, but the opposing team does not agree. Which of the following X-rays would be most useful to verify the claims of the player?

options.B: X-ray of the hands and wrist
options.D: X-ray of the elbow and hip

questions.explanation: The X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 14-year-old boy is X-ray of the hands and wrist. The bone age of a child indicates his/her level of biological and structural maturity. Methods used for bone age estimation are Greulich-Pyle atlas (more common) and Tanner-Whitehouse method. Note: There is overlap in the age ranges for X-ray of choice. Age - X-ray of choice: 3 to 9 months - X-ray shoulder, 1 to 13 years - X-ray of choice - Single film of X-ray hands and wrist, 12 to 14 years - X-ray elbow and hip.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Head reaches 90% of adult size at 1 year
options.B: Lymphoid growth follows a sigmoid-shaped pattern
options.C: Perinatal period is between 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth
options.D: Growth of a child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal

questions.explanation: Growth of a child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal. During fetal life, the growth of the head occurs before that of the neck, and arms grow before legs. The distal parts of the body, such as hands, increase in size before the upper arms. Growth rate of different tissues: Growth denotes a net increase in size/mass of tissues. Cephalocaudal head development denotes maturation of functions: neck, trunk, and upper limbs, then lower limbs. Distal to proximal: hands increase in size before upper arms. Proximal to distal: hand use is learned before the use of fingers. Percent of adult size: 200, 100. Neural, lymphoid, general, genital. 0: birth, 10 years, 20 years. Brain growth: at the age of 1 month, the head size is about 36% of the expected head size in adults. It doubles in the first year of life to 72% and becomes 83% of adult size at 2 years. Lymphoid growth: it is prominent in mid-childhood. It peaks at 4-8 years and regresses subsequently. Gonadal growth: it stays dormant during childhood and shows a rise with the onset of puberty. Somatic growth: general body growth shows an S-shaped curve. It is rapid during the fetal period and the first 3-4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably. Note: WHO defines the perinatal period from 22 weeks of gestation (or ≥500 g) up to 7 days after birth.

questions.question: A young boy is brought to the clinician by his parents with complaints of impulsive behavior and decreased levels of attention at school and everyday activities. The clinician is suspecting a case of ADHD. Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of ADHD?

options.A: Symptoms begin before 7 years of age
options.B: Symptoms should be present for at least 6 months
options.C: Should be reported by independent observers
options.D: Behavior must be developmentally inappropriate in two or more settings

questions.explanation: Attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD) must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria. It was 7 years as per the previous DSM-4 criteria. Treatment: Presynaptic dopaminergic agonists, commonly called psychostimulant medications, including methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, amphetamine, and various amphetamine and dextroamphetamine preparations are used. DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for attention-deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): 1. A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity/impulsivity present for at least 6 months, that interferes with functioning or development. 2. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms were present before 12 years of age. 3. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms are present in 2 or more settings (e.g., at school [or work] or at home) and is documented independently. 4. There is clear evidence of clinically significant impairment in social, academic, or occupational functioning. 5. Symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, or another psychotic disorder, and are not better accounted for by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, anxiety disorder, dissociative disorder, personality disorder, substance intoxication or withdrawal).

options.B: Short stature is defined as a height below the 5th percentile.
options.C: Puberty in this child will be normal.

questions.explanation: Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay. Other options: The WHO growth charts are based on the Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). The National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts that were used in the past. Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard. Puberty will be delayed in this child.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement from the following.

options.A: Children with pica are at increased risk of megaloblastic anemia
options.B: Breath-holding spells are associated with hypertonia85
options.C: Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension
options.D: Bedwetting after a period of 3 months of dryness at night is called secondary enuresis

questions.explanation: Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension. It is a self-limiting habit disorder,usually seen between 6 months to 2 years.Option A: Pica is persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month. It hampersthe development of the child and requires clinical attention. Children with pica are at an increasedrisk of lead poisoning, iron-deficiency anemia, and parasitic infections.Option B: Breath-holding spells: It is preceded by a provocative event such as anger. Crying stopsat full expiration. Child may have apnoea, cyanosis, pallor, hypotonia, or even loss ofconsciousness, and generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS). Subtypes include cyanotic, pallid, andmixed episodes. Seizures and cardiac causes should be ruled out. Parents should be reassuredthat breath-holding spells are self-limiting.Option D: Enuresis:• When the child has never been dry, it is called primary enuresis.• When the bedwetting starts after a minimum period of six months of dryness at night, it istermed as secondary enuresis.• Nocturnal enuresis is caused due to maturational delay. In a normal individual, antidiuretichormone (ADH) levels usually peak between 4 am and 8 am. This circadian rhythm is impaired innocturnal enuresis, leading to bedwetting.• Treatment - Behavioural therapy with positive reinforcement, bladder alarms, and desmopressinreserved for cases resistant to behavioural therapy.

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy was found to have a height for age 2 standard deviations below the median. Furthermore, his bone age was found to be equal to chronological age. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.explanation: Familial short stature is most likely as bone age is equal to chronological age. Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty. Bone age is less than chronological age in all other causes of short stature, such as constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes.
